citation.article-title: Recharacterization of Pseudomonas fulva Iizuka and Komagata 1963, and proposals of Pseudomonas parafulva sp. nov. and Pseudomonas cremoricolorata sp. nov.
citation.source: The Journal of General and Applied Microbiology

p.s: Description of Pseudomonas parafulva sp. nov.
Pseudomonas parafulva (parafulva pa. ra. ful'va; Gr. prefix para like; L. fem. adj. fulvus, yellow; N. L. fem. adj. parafulva fulva-like)
Cells are rods, measuring 0.6 to 0.8 by 1.4 to 1.6 μm, with rounded ends.
Gram negative.
The cells occur singly, rarely in pairs, and are motile with polar flagella.
Endospores are not formed.
Granules of poly-β-hydroxybutyrate do not accumulate in the cells.
Colonies on nutrient agar are smooth, entire, flat to convex, and pale yellow.
A water-insoluble yellow pigment is produced on nutrient agar and Tryptic Soy Agar (Difco).
A water-soluble fluorescent pigment is not produced on Pseudomonas agar F, King B medium, or Kato and Ito's P-1 medium.
No pyocyanin is produced on Pseudomonas agar P.
Growth occurs on glutamate agar.
Metabolism is strictly respiratory.
Oxidative but not fermentative.
Catalase and oxidase are produced.
Nitrate is not reduced to nitrite in nitrate broth.
Nitrate respiration is negative.
Arginine dihydrolase is produced.
Levan is not produced from sucrose.
Starch and casein are not hydrolyzed.
Growth occurs at 37°C but not at 41°C.
Growth does not occur at pH 3.6.
Cleavage of protocatechuate is of the ortho type.
The assimilation pattern is shown in Table 5.
DNA base composition is 60 mol%.
The major fatty acids are C16:0, C16:1, and C18:1, and major 3-hydroxy fatty acids are C10:0 and C12:0.
The major quinone is ubiquinone 9.
Distributed to rice paddy.
The type strain is AJ 2129T (IFO 16636=JCM 11244=NRIC 0501), of which DNA base composition is 60.0 mol%.
This strain was isolated from Japanese rice paddy by Iizuka and Komagata in 1963 (Iizuka and Komagata, 1963c).
